Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech and restricts the power of regular citizens in democracy.
It creates a division between different classes of citizens, privileging politicians, journalists, and educational institutions.
Excessive fines will lead to more restrictive digital services, stifling free expression.
Determining truth is complex and evolving, making it difficult to legislate against misinformation.
The bill's broad application affects smaller platforms and foreign entities disproportionately.
The bill contradicts the News Media Bargaining Code, limiting digital services' ability to address misinformation.
It erodes democratic principles, marginalizes minority voices, and restricts the free flow of information.
Notable Quotes: The bill creates a distinct division between different classes of citizens, with politicians, journalists, and members of educational institutions given the power to spread information, whether true or false.
The excessive fines imposed by the bill will lead to digital services becoming more restrictive with speech than ever before.
The nature of knowledge and information constantly evolves, and what was once considered factual can be disproven later.
The bill's extraterritorial reach extends Australian law disproportionately onto foreign entities, creating uncertainty and limiting legitimate global internet access.
